Title: Alternating harmonic sum $\sum_{k\geq 1}\frac{(-1)^k}{k^3}H_k$
Content:
How to analytically prove $$\sum_{k\geq 1}\frac{(-1)^k}{k^3}H_k=-\frac{11\pi^4}{360}+\frac{\ln^42-\pi^2\ln^22}{12}+2\mathrm{Li}_4\left(\frac12\right)+\frac{7\ln 2}{4}\zeta(3) $$ As O.L answer where 
$$H_k = \sum_{n\geq 1}^{k}\frac{1}{n}.$$ Addition So far I developed the following $$\sum_{k\geq 1} \frac{H_k}{k^2} \, x^{k}  = \text{Li}_3(x)-\, \text{Li}_3(1-x)+\, \log(1-x) \text{Li}_2(1-x) +\frac{1}{2}\log(x) \log^2(1-x)+\zeta(3)$$ where $\text{Li}_3(x)$ is the trilogarithm . For the derivation see http://www.mathhelpboards.com/f10/interesting-logarithm-integral-5301/ Update A frined on another site gave the following answer

###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
assumption: 
$H_k$ is the $k$-th harmonic number defined as $H_k = \sum_{n=1}^{k} \frac{1}{n}$.
problem: 
Prove that $$\sum_{k\geq 1}\frac{(-1)^k}{k^3}H_k=-\frac{11\pi^4}{360}+\frac{\ln^42-\pi^2\ln^22}{12}+2\mathrm{Li}_4\left(\frac12\right)+\frac{7\ln 2}{4}\zeta(3).$$
###END_OF_FORMAT###

Original_Problem:
assumption:

problem: 
Prove that $$\sum_{k\geq 1}\frac{(-1)^k}{k^3}H_k=-\frac{11\pi^4}{360}+\frac{\ln^42-\pi^2\ln^22}{12}+2\mathrm{Li}_4\left(\frac12\right)+\frac{7\ln 2}{4}\zeta(3).$$
